text: Shiny black loafers. Black pants, three inches too long. BOOM UP, stopping at a boy's hand reaching into the black suit jacket pocket. Pulls out a WOMAN'S GOLD NECKLACE wit LOCKET. He holds the locket. Rubs it gently with his thum CONTINUE TO BOOM UP. We now SEE THE BOY'S FACE. This is JOE LAMB, 14. On the precarious edge of adulthood looks out at the horizon with stricken eyes. He moves forward and we PAN, so we're BEHIND HIM NOW. In frosty distance, past countless leafless trees and modest homes, is a STEEL MILL. Smokestacks and structures. The lifeblood of this late 70's town.
Close on CHARLES' MOTHER AND FATHER, funeral attire. She looks out of the window sadly; heartsick and concerned. Behind her, he picks at his plate of food.
I'm so worried for that boy.
Joe's gonna be okay. 2.
...she was everything to him.
Jack's gonna step up. He's a good man.
But he was never really a father...I don't think he ever...understood Joe.
(maybe a little concerned
Joe's gonna be okay. But his wife isn't so sure. Then, BOYS' HUSHED VOICES:

CHARLES (we'll see him in a moment) LEANS FORWARD, reachi for food on a buffet table. Charles' leaning has revealed CARY, a blonde kid in a dark blue sport jacket and tie, a PRESTON, pale and smart, in a DARK SWEATER:
What do you think was in the coffin?
Jesus, shut up.
I mean cause of how she died.
... you weren't wondering that?
No, I'm eating macaroni salad. We now see CHARLES, big and in an ill-fitting BLACK SUIT, MARTIN, good looking, in a shirt and tie, at the buffet:
I was thinking that, about the coffin.
I don't know how you guys can eat. 3.

Try a Goddamn turkey roll and you'll discover how. They're delicious. CUT WIDE TO REVEAL that we are in a modest Ohio house in year 1979. At a wake. Forty-odd friends and neighbors, da dressed. Quiet discussions. Some crying.
Either nothing was in there, or like whatever they scraped up--
Jesus -- guys--
I heard it crushed her completely. At least keep your voices
A steel beam-- those things weigh a ton. Literally. If it had been open casket, I would not be eating right now. Despite the turkey rolls.
Hey-- Lucy. They look up -- in the other room, a dog (mutt, Lucy) has jumped on a guest, for food. JACKSON LAMB, Joe's father, black suit, moves to the dog, walks her out of shot.
Bet Joe's not gonna wanna do my movie anymore.
Why?
Why do you think why? The story. It's about the living dead.
His mother's not a zombie.
But she's dead, shithead.
Those turkey rolls are pretty good. 4.
Told you.

A WIDE SHOT. A grey, snow-covered, early February day her LILLIAN, OHIO. Many cars are parked outside the house, notably a SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT SQUAD CAR in the driveway. Joe, a vision of black on white in his too-big black suit now sits on a small swing set he hasn't used in years. He solemnly looks down at the LOCKET he still holds. No d trying to reconcile the fact that it no longer hangs arou his mother's neck. Then a SOUND. Joe looks up. A CAR has arrived -- a distinct 1968 BUICK GSX -- a YELLOW MUSCLE C with a BLACK RACING STRIPE down its center. Joe watches a the car sits there for a moment. Then a MAN gets out. Som Joe has seen before, but doesn't know personally. A man i his early 40's, in jeans and a work shirt. He's not exact sloppy, but if you look closely, you could tell he's been drinking. This is LOUIS DAINARD. Joe watches Louis carefully as he moves to the house, to porch and inside the house. Joe's eyes glued on the house a while. Then he looks back to the locket. He OPENS IT, a stares at the picture inside (which we do not see). And a stares, TEARS come to his eyes. A moment broken by the SOUND OF RAISED VOICES -- Joe turn toward the house. After a beat, the SOUND of something BREAKING -- something glass. Then the house BACK DOOR bur open -- Joe cranes his neck -- and what he sees he'll nev forget: his father, Jack, leading an in-pain and HAND-CUF Louis Dainard from the house and into the rear of the squ car. When he slams the back door, he sees Joe. Sort of freezes as their eyes lock. But Jack's more uncomfortable

I'll be home soon. And Jack gets into the car and drives away. Joe watches t drive off. And after a beat, he looks down at the locket again. Mom's just gone. Finally he CLOSES IT -- and we he an oddly LOUD SNAP and our SCREEN GOES BLACK. Over darkness: APPLAUSE -- then a LONE VOICE: "I want you to want me!" DRUMS kick in, CHEAP TRICK BLASTS. CUT TO: 5.

Hundreds of KIDS eagerly leave their last day of school f the year, winter a memory. GIRLS emphatically embrace eac other good-bye. BOYS run off, just happy to be out. Lots "Have a great summer!" DOLLY WITH Joe, who walks through the crowd alone, backpa on shoulder. Suddenly Charles is there, red-faced -- he hands Joe PAGE
That was the longest day ever-- here.
What's this?
New scene, check it out. Let's hit the 7.
(as he reads) You hear Martin barfed in the hall?
I know, does that guy ever not barf? Keep reading.
-- I am reading. -- Not carefully. Focus, this is important. -- Detective Hathaway has a wife?
I think it might help make my movie better. I need two things: a better story and production value. They head across the street to the 7-Eleven. Suddenly Car there, a BURN WRAP on his right arm now:
Martin booted all over his locker, it was the grossest one yet-- Let Joe focus, he's reading.
After he ate two boxes of Mike and Ikes-- never seen so many colors in my life. Will you shut up a minute? 6.
Who's gonna play the wife, Jen?
No way -- did I tell you what she did with my top hat?
Oh yeah, that was bad.
What wife?
Alice Dainard. Joe stops. His friends don't. PUSH IN ON HIM --
As they head to the doors:
I was returning that book on codes and ciphers-- she was in the silent reading section -- I thought, "Screw it." So I asked her if she'd play Hathaway's wife.
You talked to Alice Dainard really?
You're not supposed to talk at all in the silent reading section--
Shut up. It's for "silent reading."
She said yes, we're filming tonight and she's driving.
Joe, Charles and Cary scan the candy aisle.
-- driving where? 7.
To the train depot -- did you not read the scene I just gave you? Does Alice have a license? Is she old enough? Whose car are we taking? Are you making this up?
Jesus, Freak Show, she offered to drive and I accepted--
(takes scene pages) Can I see --?
-- was she nice? Why is she doing this? I don't understand, we don't even know her--
Maybe she just wants to be in a good movie, y'ever think of that?
I don't think that's what it is--
I've been working on this movie for months. I'm just trying to make it good.
(reading, disapproving) Hathaway's married now? Really? Charles swipes the pages from critic Cary.
What was she reading?
... what?
In the silent reading section, what was Alice reading?

Who gives a rat's ass what she was reading-- the festival deadline's in one week -- my movie's gotta be great! 8. CHARLES' SUPER 8 MOVIE BEING PROJECTED ON A MOVIE SCREEN. SLOWLY PUSH IN ON THE SCREEN: kids earnestly playing adul

DARKNESS. Then a DOOR OPENS. It's DETECTIVE HATHAWAY (pla by MARTIN), in silhouette. He enters. It's an old WAREHOU dirty, cobwebbed, crowded with CRATES, old MACHINERY, CHEMICAL BARRELS and JUNK. The Detective turns on his FLASHLIGHT -- aims it -- sweeps it across the space -- th light HITTING THE LENS for a moment. The Detective walks through the spooky, dark space. A low growling industrial DRONE makes the whole place oddly cre Then: A SOUND -- quick but strange -- slithering -- and t Detective aims his flashlight -- tense. He watches. Waits see where he's aiming the light, which cuts through THICK DUST in the air. It's an old office door, ajar. Hathaway is still. Nervous. Watching the door -- waiting it to open... and then -- from the darkness BEHIND HIM -- terrifying open-mouthed ZOMBIE APPEARS -- ATTACKS -- and Detective TURNS -- his flashlight KNOCKED TO THE GROUND - and Hathaway falls too -- the wild-eyed gaping-mouthed Zo DROOLING as it tries to bite Hathaway's flesh -- we recog that the Zombie is CARY. Actually, not a bad performance. Detective pulls out his GUN -- but the Zombie grabs his w -- they wrestle with the gun -- the Zombie wanting to rip into Hathaway's neck -- but Hathaway sees three SHARP-TIP NAILS sticking out of an old piece of WOODEN CRATE -- and after a significant struggle, Hathaway PUSHES THE ZOMBIE so his head is IMPALED BY THE NAILS -- which we see ENTER SKULL!!! The Zombie (stuck to the crate via the nails) SCREAMS AND DIES and just at Hathaway catches his breath IMAGE DIMS AND FREEZES; the projector has just been STOPP We are in:

Board games, books, records, a stereo, toys, and magic. S 8 film equipment and paraphernalia. Movie ONE SHEETS hang CARRIE, HALLOWEEN, EARTHQUAKE and NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEA No sports memorabilia. Charles turns on the lights, looks anxiously at Joe:
That was a good zombie murder.
Yeah, but it's not a st-- thank you for that-- it's not a story yet.
Older kids enter this film festival -- I'm competing with fifteen- and sixteen-year-olds, who have better stories and cars and production value, I've got nothing!
Charles! Dinner! As he tosses Joe a SUPER 8 FILMMAKER MAGAZINE:
I'm coming!
There's a whole article in there about stories, you should read it, it explains everything.
(looks at magazine) I don't understand how the wife makes it a story--
Jesus, that's what I've been explaining: in the scene we're filming tonight, the wife telling the detecting she's scared for him, that she loves him-- Charles!
-- so when he investigates the zombie stuff you'll be scares -- you'll feel something -- because you don't want him to die because they love each other! Does that make sense?
I just can't believe you talked to Alice Dainard.
You're impossible.
(opens the door, whispers) Midnight. Okay? Don't forget. 10.
I won't forget.
Read this. Joe just nods and looks at the magazine.

A hectic FAMILY: Charles' mother cooks. JEN, his smoking 17-year-old sister, ANGRILY sets the table where his fath pays bills. Pale 15-year-old sister PEG does a PUZZLE. Tw YEAR-OLD BOYS bicker over an action figure. TV in the liv room plays a MATCH GAME. Joe and Charles enter.
Mom, it's not fair that I can't go to Wendy's. Every single person is going except me!
Then every single person can tell you how it was --
Move the puzzle, get the napkins.
It's your turn to babysit.
So...
Get off that thing.
Mom, why can't I switch with Charles?
Because you crushed Charles' top hat, you ever think of that? Disgusted, Jen LOUDLY sets Charles' place as --
Oh, really, guess what? We're switching. 11. Charles grabs a roll.
Guess what, no we're not.
Charles take these to the table! Benji, it's time for dinner. Hey,
Goodnight, Mrs. Kaznyk--
Grab a seat, we have lots of food.
Oh no thanks, Ma'am, I'm okay. (to Charles, loaded) "See you tomorrow."
Later days.
There's always a place for you here, you know that--
Oh, yessir. Thank you. Joe leaves; Charles' parents share a look of pity for Joe

An anomalous moment in this small steel town: the sun set through the distant trees and it's beautiful, despite the distant belching SMOKESTACKS. Joe leaves Charles' house a CROSSES THE STREET to his own. SQUAD CAR in the driveway.

Joe comes into the kitchen through the BACK DOOR. Lucy th dog greets him. A TV is head somewhere. NIGHTLY NEWS repo on the ONGOING CLEAN-UP OF THREE MILE ISLAND. A half-empt BEER BOTTLE on the table. Joe peeks into the living room but no one's there. Joe looks around for his father. Heads down the hallway. Stops when he sees something off camera. We HOLD on Joe's face, sort of quietly stunned. 12. And we se his POV: Jack, Joe's father, in uniform pants a shirt, sits on the edge of the bathtub, head in his hands quietly CRYING. Joe is stunned, staring at his dad. But he can't look awa And when he finally starts to head off, Jack looks up. Jo mind scrambles for something to say, but Jack sniffles, g it together, quick. Puts on a strong face.
Hey -- I'll be out in a minute-- Joe nods as Jack forces a smile and closes the bathroom d HOLD ON JOE. Stunned and heartsick.

Commodores quietly sing "EASY" on the PA. Joe and his fat in civvies, sit beside each other at the counter. Jack ea beef stew and reviews office paperwork, not looking at hi son. Joe eats a grilled cheese, deeply lonely and not eve knowing it. Jack pulls out a PAMPHLET, and places it on the table:
It's a six-week program, hands-on training with college coaches.
You'll like it. I know I did. Joe looks at the pamphlet for HEWITT SPORTS CAMP. Images happy, smiling, healthy ATHLETIC KIDS. Not his thing.
I thought I was going to have the summer for myself--
Things have obviously changed for us. And it'd be good for you to spend some time with kids who don't run around with-- cameras and
I gotta help Charles finish his movie.
I have nothing against your friends. I like your friends.
Except Cary, who can't stop lighting things on fire. You'll like it there.

It's what we both need. Joe looks back at the pamphlet -- his other hand coming u from under the table -- and Jack sees that Joe is HOLDING MOTHER'S LOCKET. Jack wants to cry again. He wants to thr that locket away, out of sight. But he just turns away. Joe stares at the pamphlet. PUSH IN on the photo of beami 15-year-old KIDS. Then CUT TO THE HUNCHBACK OF NOTRE DAME

TIGHT ON QUASIMODO; a plastic, painted AURORA model. RACK FOCUS to the paintbrush that comes into frame -- FOLLOW I JOE, holding the brush, at his desk, making a model. A bo room recently devoid of a mother's oversight; a mess. COM BOOKS and other PLASTIC MODELS, all built and painted by CARS and CREATURES and a TRAIN. His bedside CLOCK RADIO (11:56 PM) quietly plays "BAKER STREET." Then a RADIO SQU - Joe grabs a KID'S WALKIE-TALKIE:
Okay, it's time -- don't get caught, over.
I won't. Over. Joe turns off the walkie -- and he grabs a small plastic FISHERMAN'S TACKLE BOX as we HEAR:
Wanna hear something gross?
I do.
No please, if you're really asking.
Midnight. Sitting on the curb with their GEAR and talking quietly, are Joe, Charles, Martin, Preston and Cary. Mart dressed in his detecting SUIT. Joe eats from a bag of Twizzlers. 14.
I sneezed so hard yesterday I shit my pants.
I debated telling you.
Thanks.
That's called a "sharteeze" by the way.
Well then I totally sharteezed in my pants. That's exactly what I'm talking about: the world is crazy, there's a name for everything...
Twizzler me. Joe passes him a Twizzler.
So... people are turning into zombies because of the chemical factory, right?
Martin? I don't see how the guy playing Detective Hathaway can ask where the zombies are coming from.
Another classic from Smartin.
I told you, I don't like it when you call me that.
I'm sorry, Smartin.
Shut up.
All the boys look. Their faces BRIGHTEN. Headlights. The stand as the car STOPS beside them -- IT'S THE YELLOW BUI

head_text.subj: WITH THE BLACK RACING STRIPE THAT PULLED UP TO JOE'S HOUS

text: DURING THE WAKE. But now, sitting in the driver's seat is year-old ALICE DAINARD. She sees Joe.
Joe Lamb?!
-- yeah?
What the hell's he doing here?
Make-up, sound and special effects.
He's the deputy's kid!
-- what? (touch flattered) -- you knew that?
Charles, I don't have a license. I can't drive with him!
You want Joe to-- stay back? I--?
It's too late! He's seeing me in this car right now.
You can trust me. My dad'll never know. I won't tell him anything. Looking away, she's pissed. All the boys in silent wait. considers, annoyed. Shakes her head. Finally:
Get in. The boys EXCITEDLY SCRAMBLE into the car.
The Buick crosses the nighttime horizon, leaving the smal town, driving through a rural landscape. 16.
You're driving very well. I'm impressed.

Alice drives. The boys shoved in the back with the gear - front Charles struggles with his backpack and camera bags he pulls out PAGES, arranging them. With her driving, the an unusual, electric energy in the air. Joe eats his Twizzlers in the back, trying not to stare at Alice.
So I wrote a couple new lines, can I show you?
What?
New lines? Charles-- what, I have new lines?
Shut up. There aren't a lot--
I'm sorta trying to drive--
What would be great is: could you cry during the scene? Can you do that?
... no...?! Cary messes with the radio. Alice moves his hand away.
Stop.
You know the first place I'm gonna drive when I get my license?
(offering to Alice) Want one? Alice looks at him in the rear view. Their eyes hold a be 17.
New Castle, Pennsylvania. Fireworks capital of America. She takes the Twizzler he offers and looks back to the ro
So I don't have any new lines, right? Because I just learned these.
Shut up.
I have never been a passenger in a vehicle without an adult driving. I'm unresolved as to how I feel about it.
The Buick WOOSHES PAST a solitary KELVIN GAS STATION. The dips into the darkness, beneath a blanket of stars.

The Buick pulls up to this small, EMPTY TRAIN STATION in middle of, essentially, nowhere. A series of HANGING LIGH illuminates the TRAIN PLATFORM. There's a small office, currently closed. No one around. The kids get out of the car.
Guys, there's an electrical socket up here.
Hey, Charles, Charles, do I have more lines?
No. But you can pick up some stuff. The boys carry many bags and the tripod. PLATFORM - Charles looks at the scene through the "lens" creates with both hands. 18.

Guys, this is going to be great. Get the lights and camera on that end, we'll shoot this direction first, like we talked about! Joe, get the mike plugged in-- make sure the new batteries are in the camera before you do the make-up!
Okay. Joe walks past Alive, who watches him. It strikes her tha Joe is Charles' lackey.
Martin sits alone with his copy of the pages, quietly rea and memorizing his lines.

"-- Sweetheart, this is my job, I have no choice." "That's nothing you need to worry about..." "What am I suppose to go to Michigan with you..." Cary grabs his paper and throws it to the wind, sending Martin running after it.
No, no, no. Cary.
Preston sets up the lights as Cary arrives to show him hi backpack full of FIRECRACKERS:
I took apart two packs of cherry bombs and made my own M-80.
Your obsession with fireworks -- and I'm saying this as a friend -- concerns me. And my mother.
Well you're a pussy. And your mom has one. Cary takes off. Martin returns with his paper. 19.
Bogus, Cary.
Charles writes in his notebook. He starts to get up...

Martin, I have a new line for you. He gets up to reveal Joe putting make-up on Alice. He wal over to Martin, Cary and Preston. Charles and Martin AD L TIGHT ON JOE'S TACKLE BOX, which opens. Inside is an assortment of MAKE-UPS, sponges, cotton balls, brushes, d wax, spirit gum, and a large jar of FAKE BLOOD. Joe is preparing to make up Alice, who sits in front of him, watching carefully as Joe prepares BASE MAKE-UP on a spon He looks to her. A beat.
You mind? Alice shakes her head: nope. Joe starts stippling the mak onto her face. He is now, via sponge, touching the face o girl he's admired for some time. After a beat:
My dad works at the mill. And she looks at him. Almost as if she were looking for something. Joe stops stippling. The tension is almost too much for him to bear.

Close you eyes. Please. He indicates the sponge: it's for the make-up. She does. starts applying the make-up to her eyelids. There's somet provocative for Joe, being so close to Alice, with her ey closed. Then, PRE-LAP:
So this is very emotional.

The lights (plugged into the car cigarette lighter) and camera (a EUMIG) are set. Alice has been made up, wears a coat with purse. Martin, in his tie, faces her. They both look over their script pages as Charles adjusts the camer 20. Joe, observing, holds the boom mike (a condenser mike tap to a broom handle), Preston wears an overcoat.
Alice: Mrs. Hathaway really doesn't want her husband to keep investiga--
I know, we read it, we get it.
Okay, I'm just directing. Martin get on your mark. Martin, you're going to have to reassure her. Do you know what "reassure her" means?
Yeah, I think so.
Okay-- we're starting on Alice's side first-- Preston: a couple seconds after "action" walk to the pay phone, make it look like this place is busy--
I know what that looks like. POP! Everyone JUMPS -- Charles turns -- Cary, laughing, h just exploded a firecracker:
Asshole, could you stop blowing shit up for two seconds and deal with the camera?
Sorry man.

Let's rehearse this -- save your real performances for when we're filming, though. Martin and Alice put away their pages -- Cary gets behind camera. Charles stands near the camera, kneeling to camer height. Joe wears headphones and holds the boom over the actors' heads. Preston holds a suitcase, ready to walk.
Ready? Here we go... action! 21. Martin and Alice now perform as their characters, DETECTI JOHN HATHAWAY and MRS. REBECCA HATHAWAY:
I'm going to stay here and investigate. I think it would be safer if you leave town.
John. I don't like it. This case. These murders.
What am I supposed to do, go to Michigan with you? Preston walks past them, acting in the background.
Mackinac Island's beautiful this time of year. We're TIGHT ON JOE NOW, watching Alice. Slowly amazed at unexpected depth and truth she brings to this role --
Sweetheart. This is my job.
The dead, coming back to life...? I think you're in danger--
I have no choice--
You do have a choice. We all do... And holy shit, Alice actually starts to cry as she perfor her lines. Not overdone, not hammy. Just fucking real.

John, I've never asked you to stop. I've never asked you to give up or walk away. Charles watches -- in awe -- he's suddenly, giddily transported. But it's JOE who, as he stares, becomes galvanized; any vague interest in Alice has just set:
But I'm asking you now-- please. For me. Don't go back. Don't leave me.
I need to know this isn't the last time I'll see you.
I just love you so much. Martin is thrown by the passion and heart of her performa
... I... I love you too... And in the heat of it, Alice looks at Charles, unsure:
Was that okay? Or... not really? Charles is stunned -- almost crying -- can't talk -- and he searches, behind him, a LIGHT --
-- uh, that was... I'm... that-- yeah, good. Just like that. Then a distant AIRHORN -- Charles looks: AN ONCOMING TRAI PUSH IN ON CHARLES, TIGHT. He turns to them all:
PRODUCTION VALUE!!! Is there film in the camera?!
-- I didn't put it in--

PUT IT IN!!! PUT IT IN!!! Joe, get the mike ready. Go, go, Preston, get in position. Costume, costume. Martin, get that tripod set up. Joe, help her with her costume. Hurry, hurry! Go! I hope we don't miss the train. Preston, get in position! Martin, you know you lines, right?! IS THE FILM IN THE
As Charles runs to Alice, takes her script pages.
I love how calm he is.

Yeah, he's a very relaxed guy. 23. Joe laughs a little as he goes -- Cary RIPS OPEN a YELLOW SUPER 8 box -- Joe grabs the mike -- Cary INSERTS the fil CLICK! Joe plugs in the mike, Charles grabs the camera:

Everyone ready...?! Be extra loud when the train passes by! Oh God, I hope it stops! You ready?! They're set to film toward Alice, the approaching train i her background -- Charles puts on the headphones --
And... ACTION! And they're shooting:
I'm going to stay here and investigate. I think it would be safer if you left town for a couple of days.
John. I don't like it. This case. These murders.
What am I supposed to do, go to Michigan with you?
Mackinac Island's beautiful this time of year.

Sweetheart. This is my job. Charles watches, beaming with excitement. Joe holds the b looks to Charles to make sure it sounds okay; this is whe notices something in the distance. HEADLIGHTS. A quarter away, a vehicle drives along the horizon. A beat. But the train is APPROACHING -- GETTING LOUDER -- which makes Joe turn back toward the train -- the thing almost upon them LOUDER AND LOUDER, so the actors begin to YELL over the

But I'm asking you now-- please. For me. Don't go back. Don't leave me. I need to know this isn't the last time I'll see you.
I just love you so much. Alice and Martin continue to yell their lines -- Charles almost LAUGHING at how good this looks -- but Joe LOOKS DESPERATELY BACK toward the headlights -- the train LIGHT

GUYS, WATCH OUT!!! Joe what the hell are y--?! -- just then BA-BA-BA-BAM!!! THE TRAIN ENGINE, HUNDREDS O

text: And then -- IT'S OVER. Just the odd, dying CHUGS and SCREECH-SCREECH- SCREECH of TRAIN WHEELS running out of momentum, HISSES o STEAM, the unnatural bending of steel. In the DUST, JOE lies frightened on the ground, eyes tigh shut. His mind races, his heart pounds -- and then: A LOU METAL BANG! Joe stands up fast, faces a MOUNTAIN of twist STEEL -- UPSIDE-DOWN TRAIN CARS PILED FRIGHTENINGLY aroun him. Just another few feet and he would've been crushed. what was that sound? Something metal? Then again: SLAM! J BACKS UP, afraid -- it was almost a LABORED GROAN -- MECHANICAL or ANIMAL?! A crazy SCREECH, another BANG, the AGAIN and AGAIN!!! We see Joe TIGHTLY GRIPPING HIS NECKLACE LOCKET IN HIS HA THEN: CRASH! -- AWFUL-LOUD -- and a TWISTED TEN-FOOT SQUA

-- Joe covers his head as the metal STABS THE GROUND, twe feet away: a TRAIN SLIDING DOOR. Joe turns to see it -- stunned -- then back to the direction of the NOISE -- but is GONE. Nothing. TIGHT ON CHARLES' CAMERA -- on its side, FINISHING UP A CARTRIDGE OF FILM.
Guys?! Joe finds MARTIN, on his knees, THROWING UP -- Martin kee throwing up, but pumps a THUMBS UP.
Martin, are you okay?! Preston, is that you?
I'm okay! Though I think I'm having a heart attack! And I have a scrape! Joe MOVES FORWARD -- up to camera -- behind him, Cary appears, smiling. This kid enjoyed the crash: 26.
Guys, did you see those explosions? That was awesome.
Has anyone seen Alice?!

I'm alive! Is anyone dead? Through the debris, steel and dust. Joe moves forward -- Charles, shaken, eyes wide, appears through the thick dus Joe moves forward, looking at, under a train WHEEL ASSEMBLY... BLOOD. A PUDDLE OF BLOOD and Joe's heart sink he moves toward it -- another woman he loves, crushed?! Charles and Preston and Cary see the blood --
-- oh God-- -- no -- nonono... Martin, still sick, calls out:
-- what? Guys, what is it? ... shit... Joe moves closer to the blood -- heartsick -- on the verg DEEP, REAL TEARS -- everything stops -- but then:
-- what's all that blood? Joe WHIPS AROUND -- standing in the dusty mess is ALICE - shaken, but absolutely alive. Joe just BEAMS.
What's the blood? -- did someone get hurt--? But JOE SUDDENLY KNOWS -- he moves to the blood -- reache below the wheels -- the others watch, freaked out --
Joe, wait -- maybe you shouldn't touch -- what are you-- careful! Joe pulls out his CRUSHED MAKE-UP KIT. He brightens:
It's my fake blood. It's fake!
What is this stuff? 27. ALICE NOTICES THAT HE'S HOLDING THE NECKLACE. Joe notices this and POCKETS IT self-consciously. PRESTON calls out:

Guys, what are these things? Joe looks -- they all move to Preston (except Cary, who h off): CRATES have spilled from a nearby split car; many shattered, revealing THOUSANDS OF SMALL WHITE-METAL CUBES which now litter the ground. Joe kneels, picks one up:
Hey, don't touch it, what are you doing?

They look like white Rubik's cubes or something. They're heavy like metal or something. There's like a billion of them. It's just a few inches per side, an UNUSUAL DESIGN. Behin them, having walked up the ANGLED SIDES of overturned tra cars, Cary calls out:
Guys, get up here. You can see everything from up here. They move up the mass of metal, revealing a VAST VIEW OF WRECK. It seems to stretch on forever. It is SOBERING.
Oh my God. ... Look at that...
According to my Uncle Seth, an accident like this is exceptionally rare.
It wasn't an accident. (turns away, eyes on the
There was a truck. On the tracks.
What? Driving on the tracks? Joe's seen it. He points. Chilled.
There. 28. Thrown fifty yards from the main wreckage is THE PICK-UP TRUCK. SHEARED IN HALF UPON IMPACT and lying in the overg grass.
How can a pick-up truck derail a train? That's impossible.

Obviously it isn't. BOOM UP from behind the SHATTERED PICK-UP as the kids approach from the wreckage. PUSH IN ON THEM as they arriv the truck and STOP; what they see makes Joe's heart pound they're stunned -- all of them. They just stop. Finally:
... holy shit...
-- is that him?
(covers her mouth)) -- yeah, it's him--
-- who?
It is, yeah, for sure-- Holy shit.
What? Who is that? WE SEE NOW: it's DR. WOODWARD -- 75, seat-belted, bloody unconscious, stuck inside the crushed wreckage. Alice mov closer -- scared and sad for him --
Dr. Woodward...? No one can take their eyes off this as, SOTTO:
That's Dr. Woodward? The science guy?
Biology.
Honors biology. 29.
Wow... I'm not in his class.
We know.
Shut up, Cary.
Remember when Old Man Woodward took your Electronic Football?
Yeah, he put it in the "dungeon," never gave it back...
The dungeon?
That trailer Woodward keeps in the school parking lot. Joe moves next to Alice, who reaches out and gently NUDGE him -- you keep expecting him to suddenly grab her --

... Dr. Woodward? But he's apparently dead; when she nudges him, he LEANS, arm drops limp from the steering wheel, where he was HOLD A PAPER, that has now fallen onto the ground. Joe picks i up. UNFOLDS IT: it's an OLD MAP -- thin, off-white paper. They hold it up, the map now backlit and obscuring Woodwa We see MARKER WRITING ON IT -- a BLACK LINE, from Nevada Dayton -- and NUMBERS written along the way.
Map of the contiguous United States... -- what's the writing?
-- dates and times. -- what's that line across?
It's a schedule for the train. But a SHADOW has appeared: A TREMBLING HAND -- before the can react, it RIPS THE MAP AWAY -- THEY ALL SCREAM AS OLD WOODWARD IS REVEALED, BLOODY EYES OPEN, in a DAZE:
-- who-- who are you? 30. They're all speechless for a moment. Finally, too loudly:
Dr. Woodward! It's Charles Kaznyk! From fourth period! You've been in an accident!

head_text.subj: BUT WOODWARD HAS REACHED INTO HIS JACKET AND PULLED OUT A

text: They will kill you. Do not speak of this -- or you -- and your parents - - will die. We're on Joe's stunned face -- but DISTANT VOICES make hi turn his head: hundreds of yards away, through the wreck,
-- guys, look -- The rest turn to look -- their minds are racing, all of t
-- we shouldn't be here--
The kids start moving away --

My dad will de-ball me! Let's get out of here!!! Now they're SPRINTING -- FLASHLIGHT MEN getting closer. Charles arrives on the platform, grabs his camera. Alice hurries past, hunting for her keys in that big purs she eyes the FLASHLIGHT MEN getting closer:

head_text.subj: MOVE YOUR ASS, WE GOTTA GO

text: Joe grabs his make-up kit -- another duffel -- runs for t car, past a whining Charles.

As the FLASHLIGHT MEN APPROACH, Joe runs and gets in the front seat, the other boys in back -- Alice SLAMS the car into REVERSE, SCREECH-BACKS UP, narrowly avoids debris, t RIDES OFF -- the FLASHLIGHT MEN arrive -- SOLDIERS -- the adrenaline pumping. One man who WALKS UP TO THE CAMERA, eyeing the vanishing car with intense suspicion: COLONEL NELEC. He then looks to the ground in front of him. CLOSE ON A FRESH, EMPTY YELLOW SUPER 8 FILM BOX. Nelec st to it, picks it up. Looks at it. Then back up at the disappearing car. We PUSH IN ON HIS BURNING EYES AND --
RRRRRRRROOOOOOOOOAAAAAARRRRRRRR! The Buick speeds past.
Overlapping mayhem, but Charles obsesses over his camera:
Holy shit, that was insane! He had a gun! An actual physical gun!
I can't believe all that just happened here! Nothing ever My whole camera lends is like happens here!!! shattered now!
My heart is pounding! That train could of killed us.
Are you okay? As Alice nervously drives, she shakes her head: no.
Oh shit, all the glass just fell out!

head_text.subj: I HAVE NEVER HAD A TEACHER AIM A

text: It's hard enough to drive without everyone yelling! 32.
Guys, keep it down!
Joe: what was Woodward talking about? I don't know, I don't know--
I'm never taking a train again.
"You'll die, your parents will die," guys, that is not good information.
Great, the focus ring just fell off!
No one cares about your CAMERA!
Am I the only one shaking?! I'm also crying --
We can't tell anyone we were there - - we can't say a thing about it -- my dad cannot find out I took his car, do you guys hear me?!
It's okay-- no one's saying anything. None of us. (to his friends) Guys -- we're not gonna say anything -- are we?! The boys all muster, "no's." Joe turns sweetly to Alice.
See? No one's gonna know. Alice nods; if not quite relieved, at least grateful for But they all stare off for a long beat... haunted.
The Buick SPEEDS AWAY... 33.

CRANE DOWN as the Buick pulls up. The dusty boys pile out They all kind of look at each other. What a night. Charle who looks at Joe for a beat, holds up his defunct camera the tripod. Joe nods. Alice finds something on the passenger seat and holds it
Joe, this is yours. Joe goes to the window. Alice holds it out: THE CUBE. He takes it with:
-- oh, thanks,
I should never have done this. She just drives away. Left there are Joe, Charles, Presto Cary and Martin. They all kind of look at Alice go.
Joe in the bath. The quiet SWISH of water as Joe holds th CUBIC OBJECT. He relives the night: he mouths explosions. Remembers the fear... then he smiles.
Joe is STARTLED AWAKE as if from a nightmare; Jack has aw him, quickly bucking his holster, urgent:

Gotta head in early -- -- okay-- Make sure you let Lucy out. -- I will -- Pull back WIDE to see Joe's room -- while in the FOREGROU is his desk, crowded with stuff. In focus, however, is th CUBED OBJECT he took from the crash site. As the shot progresses, you may notice that THE CUBE HAS CHANGED SHAP THE VOLUME IS THE SAME, BUT THE CORNERS HAVE EXTENDED.
You gonna -- what, you with Charles today? Yeah, I'll be with Charles-- Make sure you get the yard. -- okay, I will. Jack heads off. 34.
TIGHT SHOT: Joe fills Lucy's FOOD DISH with kibble. No do
Joe hurries across the street.

Typical Kaznyk bustle: Father busily packs sack lunches. Jen eats cereal, reads a magazine. One Twin plays HANDBAL loudly against a wall. Peg keeps walking through the scen with clothes. Mother cooks, says to the other twin (in gr
Mom, come on!
No. You're not wearing that. No one in this house is wearing that.
Compared to Debbie's these are long.
Just listen to your mother.
I can't wear these or go to Wendy's party? This is not fair.
Jennifer Anne, not fair is Africa.
Mom's racist.
Are there anymore English muffins?
I don't know, go check.
Peg, tell the twins to stop.
They don't listen to me. 35.
Hi, Joe. It all continues as Joe has entered from the front door.
Morning, Mr. Kaznyk--
Hi, Joe. Did you hear about the train accident?
Uh... no.

It's on the news. Joe is moving toward the living room, where Charles sits the sofa, eyes glued to the TV, A TRAIN CRASH BEING REPOR ON THE LOCAL NEWS; HELICOPTER SHOT of the wreck. The CHYR READS, "TRAIN DERAILED - AIR FORCE AIDS CLEAN UP." Joe si beside Charles. They both watch, stunned, as a PHOTO OF D WOODWARD appears on the TV, with the heading "DRIVER OF T
Can you believe this?
No.
It's on the news. That means it's real.

Meanwhile, local science teacher Thomas Woodward is still being treated by Air Force medical personnel after last night's train derailment. Woodward apparently fell asleep at the wheel of his pick-up truck, which was hit by the speeding train at approximately one AM. Eighty-two train cars were thrown from the tracks in the derailment, the largest such accident in Ohio's history. The condition of Woodward, who has taught at Lillian Middle School for the past six years, remains unknown. 36. Both stare at the train crash, stunned. Finally, quietly:
... Looks like a disaster movie, doesn't it...? And we PUSH IN ON CHARLES, going from depressed and lost
... oh my God, Joe... that's
-- what?
We can use this -- we can film it --
(starts to smile) -- you wanna go back?!
(turns to him) --okay-- Holy shit, that's mint. You're a total brain--! We gotta get the camera fixed and the film developed from last night-- I gotta go steal some more money from my mom!
Joe and Charles ride their bikes into town, across a BRID the massive STEEL MILL in the background --
If any of the footage from last night is usable, that means we need Alice to play the wife again.
Yeah, I thought she was good.
She was mint, but she's never gonna do it.
I think she will. 37.
There's no way. You heard what she said.
But that was before the new pages, right?
You honestly think she cares about the scenes?

TILT DOWN from the town's WATER TOWER -- Joe and Charles their bikes underneath it, crossing Main Street -- two la MILITARY TRUCKS drive past, we may note the Airman in the passenger seat SCANS THE AREA with a handheld device.
Man, did you hear what she said last night? "I never should have done this!" Dude, she was totally wigged!
Yes, she was, we all were.
Did you see her face?
Yeah, I saw her face.
Man, what's wrong with you?
Nothing. I think she's going to do it. They park their bikes outside OLSEN CAMERA AND HI-FI.
The book opens -- Joe's finger goes down -- finds "LOUIS DAINARD" and the phone number. We're in: 38.
Joe at the counter, DIALING THE ROTARY PHONE, Charles beh him with DONNY, the 19-year-old, dark-haired, bearded salesman with a big collared button-down shirt.
Lens is cracked. Focus ring broke.
Ya think it's fixable? Joe HEARS Alice's phone number RINGING.
I think it's cheaper to buy a new one.
We're screwed, man, it's over!
We can use my dad's camera -- it's got sound and-- Hello?
Alice-- hi, it's Joe. Lamb. As Charles opens the camera, pulls out the film:
Hi...
So we have some new scenes. For the movie. We were hoping you'd be in `em.
Oh-- no. No, I'm done with that. Joe twirls a hanging Kodak "RELIVE THE MEMORIES" SUPER 8 PROMOTIONAL SIGN, speaking in a soft voice:
Really? `Cause these are really good scenes. Charles hands the film cartridge to Donny.
We need this developed as soon as possible -- can you do overnight? 39.
Asshole, no one can do overnight. You wanna buy some pot? Charles reacts; he's never smoked anything.
... no, thank you.
You guys are weak.
I'm watching the crash on the news.
Yeah, I know, I saw it.
Are you okay?
Well, what's the fastest you can do?
I can make it a rush, you get the film back in three days-- what's your sister up to? The hot one, not the other one.
I don't know.
I should go.
-- wait, hold on -- lemme come over and show you the pages, okay? I'll be right there. No, d--
Lower-lower-middle class house, set against woods. Joe wi Alice at her front door. She seems unnerved:
I don't care what Charles wants-- I said no on the phone. 40.
You totally did, that's true, I know, but--
And now you're at my house.
I am, which-- under normal conditions I would nev--
It's too weird after last night-- I don't understand how you guys can keep working on your stupid movie, I really don't.
We have to-- while the crash is still there. (waits, anxious, then,
... please...?
(she considers, then:) No. But Alice's eyes have flicked to the Buick, pulling up.
You should go. Joe watches Louis get out of the car -- the man who got arrested at his mother's wake -- carrying a small grocery bag. He sees Joe and darkens as he approaches:
What's this?
He was just inviting me to a party. Joe steps back as Louis arrives; Louis seems to hate Joe, at the same time, can barely look at him:
She's not going to your party.
Yessir. Louis throws Alice a dark, resentful glare. 41.
You know better than this. She nods, uncomfortable. Louis turns to Joe:
You get outta her. You go home and don't come back, I don't wanna see you. Louis goes back inside. Alice follows, turns to Joe. As awkward moment between them. Then, quietly, conflicted:
I'll do it.
-- what? She closes the door. Alone, despite it all, Joe is happy. his smile, we HEAR LOUD POPS: BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM!

Martin -- as Detective Hathaway -- FIRES A GUN -- shootin CARY, dressed in a dirty suit, as a man TURNING INTO A ZO -- his eyes WIDE AND GLOSSY WHITE -- and as he is HIT BY BULLETS, he SLAMS HIS HAND ONTO HIS CHEST -- BLOOD BURSTS OVER HIM and he FALLS PAINFULLY TO THE GROUND. We then fi CHARLES, behind his camera, yelling out:
CUT! That was mint! So good! And it looked huge with the train! Wow! Joe: go reload the cap gun!

WIDE SHOT, rising PAST SIX BICYCLES, thrown to the ground a typical kid jumble. Charles, Joe and Preston, with Joe' dad's KODAK CAMERA on tripod, have been filming, their ge scattered. KEEP MOVING OVER THEM, to Martin and Alice, wh were on camera. Beyond them, in the valley, the TRAIN CRA seems to go forever. MILITARY TRUCKS, TENTS and SOLDIERS. HELICOPTERS buzz in the distant sky. Joe moves over to Al who looks out at the crash. During all this:
We'll get the other direction next - - Alice, that was mint-- Martin, go a little faster next time. 42.
I'll try, but I'm still crying about last night, I feel like I'm crazy. Cary sits, pulls off the CUT-OUT PING PONG BALLS that wer covering his closed eyes.
Did it really look good? My death? CLOSE ON JOE as he arrives beside Alice, who looks out at train, haunted. Quiet:
... what do you think happened...? Joe stops reloading the gun, looks out, gets lost as well
You mean why he crashed the train?
I just got a horrible feeling. Martin has arrives there too. Preston too:
Anyone else still shaking from the crash?
I got in my parents' bed last night. Haven't done that since I was eleven. Joe suddenly WALKS AWAY FROM THEM, back toward the camera
... did I just insult him? Joe grabs the camera, near Charles:

-- dude, what are you doing? Joe moves the camera back to Alice -- he looks through th lens -- uses the ZOOM -- and WE SEE JOE'S POV -- the CRAS ZOOMED IN -- he PANS from ONE CAR TO ANOTHER. Alice watches Joe, who peers into the camera for a long b finally standing up, looking out at the crash: 43.
That whole thing's an Air Force train.
-- what?
The kids sit at a table at the window. The CAR LOT is acr the street. They're talking excitedly but quietly:
I make models-- plastic ones-- you know, glue `em, paint `em--
And he's not embarrassed by that.
Looks who's talking, Math Camp. A WAITRESS is there, delivering more FOOD --
Thanks, could I have a coffee, please? Cream on the side?
(really?) Sure. She heads off. Cary smiles at Alice.
He is so sophisticated.
Shut up, I like coffee. No one likes coffee.
Keep going.
Air Force trains -- even models -- have these hooks...
Ooo! Ooo ooo ooo! They do -- for when their train cars are put on transport ships. 44.
Every car in that crash had hooks, every one...
Joe: stop talking about it.
Am I the only one who doesn't understand what this all means?
Probably, Smartin.
Shut up, I don't like that--
Dr. Woodward had that map. He drove onto the tracks. Maybe there was something-- -- he wanted to destroy, he wanted to destroy? yeah.
Please shut up, all of you.
I say he was just sick of being old and wanted to kill himself.
He had a gun, why not use that?
There are infinitely more effective ways to commit suicide: pills,
Pussy, stop pulling the fries away. I ordered these for a reason. -- he gets all possessive with his fries, it's so annoying.
You could jump from a building.
Fall down stairs.
Well, that's not really effective. 45.
So, if it's Air Force, what would the Air Force have on a train?
SHHHHJESUS! You heard what the Old Man said, we can't talk about this! (to waitress, with coffee) -- thank you, very much.
Drowning, hari kari, also known as seppuku--?
Excuse me, could we please get another order of fries because my friend here is fat?
Funny, Chompers, at least I don't use a booster seat.
What was your teacher even talking about? Who are we supposed to be afraid of anyway?

I don't wanna find out -- guys, we gotta forget we were there. Joe, seriously... you really wanna take a chance that something could happen to your dad, too? This lands for Joe -- for all of them -- as we CUT TO:

The massive train wreck that goes on for a mile. Hundreds MILITARY work to clean up fast. A truck DRIVES PAST CAMER taking us to Jack and Nelec, who WALK together amid the debris. Choppers land and take off in the background:
Yes, I understand, this crash has caused a whole mess of confusion. 46.
As you can expect, the local authorities are trying to figure out just what happened here as well as how to help you out.
It's under control. It'll be a very fast clean-up.
Colonel, there isn't anything I should know, is there?
Not that I can think of, Deputy. I understand you have concerns about our cargo.
I'd like to see that manifest, yes.
That's not going to be possible.
Colonel, I've got a lot of people in my town that are gonna want to know what's taking place.
-- what town is that?
... Lillian.
Deputy, if you're asking me if we had any dangerous property on board this train, I can assure you the answer's no.
Colonel.
Excuse me. Jack looks at Nelec -- not quite believing him... 47.
Jack is with Sheriff Pruitt, who stands, distracted, pick up reports from his desk, on his way out.
They gave me the run around for two hours before I was allowed to talk to anyone.
I'd say they have their hands full, wouldn't you?
Nelec -- the Colonel -- refused to show me their manifest, said they were carrying mostly airplane parts-
It's Air Force, Jack. Airplane parts sorta make sense.

Sheriff, I'm telling you, there's something else going on -- they're taking molds of tire tracks -- now why would they be doing that? Who are they looking for? And they're packing these weird little cubes into crates and they're--
Weird little cubes?
--yeah, into these red trucks, dozens of these trucks -- and I'm telling you, they're scrambling to get the hell outta there--
I'd say that's a good thing, wouldn't you?
Sheriff, I think you need to go check it out.
And I think you need a break.
Jack, I've been telling you this since Elizabeth.
You're a good deputy. But you need to take a vacation.
Go home. Take off your uniform. Go fishing. And give your son a hug. Pruitt walks off. Jack, unsettled, watches him go.

FINGERS TAPPING -- they're fingers on a COUNTER, a WALKMA sitting beside them. BOOM UP to 23-year-old BREEN, who di the BLONDIE he's listening to. He is alone in the station store. Behind him, 60-year-old SHERIFF PRUITT enters.
Hey Breen, I'm not sure Edie's paying you to listen to the radio. Breen doesn't respond. The sheriff throws a candy bar at
Breen. Breen pulls off the headphones.
Hey, Sheriff.
What's that?
Walkman. It's like a stereo, play your own cassette tapes.
You wanna try it?
(pays for the candy bars) I don't think so. Kids walking around with their own stereos. Just what we need. It's a slippery slope. He exits the store.
... yessir. Pruitt heads out; Breen puts the headphones on again. 49.

We see we're at the lonely gas station the kids drove pas earlier. Pruitt's SQUAD CAR filling up, the only car here High overhead, a yellow KELVIN sign TURNS atop a tall pol near the road. Pruitt crosses to his car. Peels the candy bar. Hearing something, he turns -- a PACK OF DOGS RUN BY

CLOSE UP of the PUMP'S SPINNING white NUMBER on black; th gallons and dollar amount blurring higher -- then A BIZAR REFLECTION -- Pruitt sees it, turns -- and what he sees i TALL AND TERRIFYING -- he DROPS THE CANDY -- GOES FOR HIS

Breen, eyes closed, blasts his Walkman (we only hear TINN MUSIC) as, through the window behind him, the rear of the squad car SUDDENLY SPRINGS UPWARD VIOLENTLY as if the FRO SECTION WAS SUDDENLY CRUSHED! PRUITT SCREAMS, MUFFLED, as CAR SLAMS back to the pavement -- LIGHTS FLICKER --
Gas PUMPING onto the asphalt, SCREAMS OF PRUITT, horrible
PRUITT'S SCREAMS END as Breen OPENS HIS EYES AND RIPS off headphones: the hell was that? He looks outside -- sees t car -- shattered windows. Confused, he heads out --

Breen moves tentatively toward the CRUSHED CAR -- quickly glances for Pruitt, who's missing. He gets close to the c confounded by what he sees -- hands shaking, he rights th pump and replaces it. His heart pounds as he starts for t building -- but SLIPS ON THE GAS -- falls hard -- looks u sees whatever's coming for him -- SCREAMS as he gets to h feet and RUNS LIKE A MOTHERFUCKER --
Breen RUSHES INSIDE -- we're WITH HIM as behind him: KKKRASH!!!! An EXPLOSION OF GLASS AND JUNK FOOD and -- 50.

WE LOOK DOWN UPON THE STATION FROM UP HIGH -- where the turning, lit KELVIN SIGN BLOCKS OUR VIEW FOR THE MOMENT - can only HEAR THE HORROR happening inside the station unt FINALLY the sign REVEALS THE STATION -- everything inside looks like it's in a BLENDER -- THERE'S A SUPER-HUMAN UPHEAVAL HAPPENING IN THERE -- and Breen's SCREAMS CONTIN as the turning Kelvin sign BLOCKS OUR VIEW AGAIN -- as th

head_text.subj: SOUND GETS UNBEARABLE, A SUDDEN CUT TO

text: A FACE. A MAKE-UP BRUSH APPLYING MAKE-UP. It's ALICE, and she's becoming a ZOMBIE. We are:

Joe makes her up -- a not half-bad, simple ZOMBIE MAKE-UP Pale skin, sunken eyes and cheekbones. In the background, other kids prepare to film. He hands her a mirror, she gazes into it, sort of amazed.
Where'd you learn how to do this?
Mostly the Dick Smith Monster Make- up Handbook. She nods. Whatever. Charles is suddenly there, with Cary:
Hey! So I'm gonna need more shots of the train crash, obviously-- you know that train model you made? Can we blow it up and film it? Joe doesn't want to do this at all. AT ALL. But...
... sure.
Mint. Gnarly! Charles and Cary head off, planning the explosions. Alice looks at him knowingly.
I don't care, they can blow it up. I can show you the train, it's nothing, it's stupid.
You wanna see it? Later? The... train? My train model? The train I made? The LIGHTS IN THE HOUSE DIM -- BROWN OUT -- then back on.
That's like the third time Dude. Bitchen. that's happened.
So how am I supposed to be a zombie?
Oh. Just be a lifeless ghoul. Someone with no soul, dead eyes. Scary. D'you ever have Mrs. Mullin?
For English? Yeah--

-- like her. But hungry, like hungry for human flesh. To make them turn into zombies, because that's what zombies do. Alice considers this -- then, after a beat, starts doing best zombie. Joe smiles, `cause it's pretty good.

Oh my God. That's really good... And Alice slowly leans in toward him -- is this performan Or is this something else--? And she PUTS HER MOUTH ON HI NECK IN A FAKE BITE, which makes Joe go still -- a shiver down his spine -- he's never felt anything like this in h life. And when she pulls back, her performance over, she' smiling. He doesn't know what to say, tries to stay cool.
... not bad.

We're NEAR THE GAS PUMPS, LOW TO THE GROUND -- DOLLY as J EDIE and MR. BLAKELY come out here. We pass SMALL SHATTER PIECES OF RED AND BLUE PLASTIC and STOP AND RACK to the G Sheriff Pruitt dropped. 52.
-- Careful, there was a gas spill. I don't even know how much fuel I've lost.
-- You don't seem to be asking a lot of questions.
-- Give this man some time, Mr. Blakely.

He's just the Deputy, he's not the Sheriff... Jack kneels by the Smith and Wesson Model 19. Jack pulls a handkerchief, lifts the fun -- PUSH IN ON the engraved initials "H.P." JACK IS ROCKED BY THIS. He opens the cyli to check if it had been fired. CUT BACK WIDE. No squad car here. Jack checks out the bro BLUE AND RED PLASTIC as he makes a walkie call:
I think this is most likely a bear attack.
Remember when I said you talk too much? Well, this is the time.
Vicky, ya heard from Sheriff Pruitt this morning?
Negative, still no word.
Vicky, I need you to have Dayton send a CS unit out to Edie's. You put out an APB on the Sheriff and Breen Haskell -- send units to their houses immediately. You copy all of that?
... copy. And Jack, we're getting a lot of unusual calls.
... what kind of unusual calls...? 53.
Angry IZZY, 65, OPENS A NEW CAR HOOD: PIECES OF THE ENGIN RIPPED AWAY, MESSY -- DOLLY WITH HIM, Jack follows:
Never seen this kinda thing before. Izzy opens ANOTHER CAR HOOD: PIECES MISSING.

What the hell am I supposed to do? Insurance company thought I was joking with him. Look at my Bonneville here-- look at this. I got a call about this car yesterday. What am I going to tell the customer? ANOTHER HOOD -- PIECES MISSING.
Having trouble with anyone lately, Izzy?

I was thinking, you should talk to Louis Dainard. I didn't help him out with financing last year, wouldn't be surprised if this was-- some sorta sick retribution. As Jack heads back to his car, THREE RESIDENTS move to hi walk with him, AD LIB:

-- Some strange shit has been -- d'you call the station going on. My antenna's gone-- yet. You need to call the our dog is gone, he hasn't station. And file a report, come home this morning -- before anything can be done Jack, my lights keep going on about it. And then we can and off. Counting on you, take care of these things. If Jack. you do that for me, I promise you, I'll handle it myself. He seems to have appeased them -- but as he turns, we see stressed he is. He stops, noticing FOUR MILITARY TRUCKS DRIVING PAST, SLOWLY, ANTENNAS atop the trucks, and the m inside seemingly scanning the area. Jack is disturbed by this. 54.
Joe rides along a hillside. Parks his bike. Walks toward edge.
Lucy. Lucy. Lucy! He stops to reveal the town of Lillian.
Joe rides the street, calling out:
Lucy! ... Lucy! WIDE SHOT as he DIPS down a neighborhood hill, sun LOW.

A community CORKBOARD. Joe posts up a piece of paper; we IT NOW IN CLOSE-UP. It's a MISSING DOG SIGN FOR LUCY. We' on Joe's face as he finishes pinning it up -- when someth he sees makes him stop. He slowly takes a step back. Then another... his eyes glued to the board. Then we see the REVERSE -- SLOWLY PULLING BACK -- REVEALI

head_text.subj: THAT THERE ARE DOZENS AND DOZENS OF BRAND NEW "DOG MISSIN

text: SIGNS POSTED ON THE BOARD. It's COVERED in them. Joe is s stunned, he doesn't notice the MILITARY TRUCKS that pass the background behind him.
KA-BAM: back door opens, Joe enters. EMPTY PIZZA BOX on t table. Jack and four POLICE OFFICERS in the living room, smoking, reviewing POLICE REPORTS, marking MAPS, taking n

head_text.subj: -- WORKING ON THE PROBLEMS THEY'RE HAVING --

text: We need more help around here.
We've got four men on the Pruitt case alone. We've called into Dayton, they'll be out in the
That's not enough. People don't feel safe here -- and you know why? `Cause they're not-- The officers agree. Joe moves into the doorway where his and other convene.
-- the Air Force isn't answering a damn question: they've got trucks at Woodward's house, looking for
They've got trucks all over town.
I saw a guy riding shotgun in one of those trucks -- had some kind of scanner in his hand --
--like a Geiger counter or

So in the spirit of moving forward and avoiding more trouble, tell us where you put your research. I know you had someone document the crash that night. Tell me who that was and I'll help you, I swear to God. On my mother's life -- if you help us now, we will take care of you.
I've seen what happens, Mr. Nelec, when you take care of people.
--I'm going to bait him. I'm going to catch him.

He's in me, you know. As I am in him. So when you see him next, as I'm sure you will... I'll be watching you, too. Nelec offers a vague, searching smile. But Woodward will - not ever -- relent. So.
